name: Orthogonal Matching Pursuit 2D in Java
body:
### Orthogonal Matching Pursuit 2D in Java.
Orthogonal Matching Pursuit in 2D (OMP2D) is an effective algorithm for sparse image representation.
It is dedicated to approximating an image as a superposition of elements chosen from two large sets,
one for each dimension, celled dictionaries.

### Installing the plugin for ImageJ
1. First Download the ImageJ application from [http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/download.html](http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/download.html) and the OMP2D plugin from [here](https://github.com/simonsm1/OMP2D/raw/master/OMP2D/OMP2D_Plugin.jar)
2. Extract ImageJ to a folder of your choice and copy OMP2D_Plugin.jar to the plugins folder within.
3. Launch the ImageJ executable and you should find OMP2D listed under the plugins menu.

![screenshot](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/simonsm1/OMP2D/master/OMP2D/screenshot.png)

or if you're running 64-bit Linux
```
$ wget http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/download/linux/ij147-linux64.zip
$ unzip ij147-linux64.zip
$ wget -P ImageJ/plugins https://github.com/simonsm1/OMP2D/raw/master/OMP2D/OMP2D_Plugin.jar
$ ./ImageJ/ImageJ
```

### Supported Images
This plugin currently supports greyscale images which are exactly divisible by 32. See example image below:

![Astro 512](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/simonsm1/OMP2D/master/OMP2D/Astro_512_grey.jpg)

### About
This plugin for ImageJ was developed by Matt Simons of Aston University, UK, for his Final Year Undergrad
Project in the Mathematics and Computing Programme (http://www.aston.ac.uk/eas/about-eas/academic-groups/mathematics/)
For references and description of the algorithm implemented in the plugin see the full report (https://www.dropbox.com/s/m4e1kc7xc1bg1qr/report.pdf).

### Acknowledgements
With thanks to [Laura Robollo-Neira](http://www.aston.ac.uk/eas/staff/a-z/dr-laura-rebollo-neira/) for supervising and supporting this project.
